fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a monad M : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {C}, an M-algebra is defined as an object X equipped with a morphism \alpha : MX \to X, such that the following two diagrams commute.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In an unbiased formulation, we require the natural transformation M^n \to M of the monad evaluated at the object X composed with \alpha : MX \to X to be equal to M^n X \xrightarrow {M^{n-1}\alpha } M^{n-1}X \to \cdots \xrightarrow {\alpha } X.
The algebras of a monad form a category \mathcal {C}^M, whose morphisms are commutative squares. This is also known as the Eilenberg–Moore category.

fr:title.text: The Eilenberg–Moore category induces the terminal decomposition of a monad

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Eilenberg–Moore category induces the terminal decomposition of a monad

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Eilenberg–Moore category together with its canonical adjunction is the terminal decomposition of a monad into adjoint functors. Hence there is a unique morphism from any decomposition to it, named the comparison functor.
Given an adjunction F \dashv G with the corresponding monad G \mathbin {\circ } F, the comparison functor is defined as sending X to GFGX \to GX, given by the counit FGX \to X.

fr:title.text: The Kleisli category is equivalent to the category of free algebras

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Kleisli category is equivalent to the category of free algebras

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given category \mathcal {C}, the Kleisli category of a monad M : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {C} is equivalent to the full subcategory of the M-algebras spanned by the free algebras.
Consider the functor from the Kleisli category to the category of free algebras, sending X to the free algebra on X. This is fully faithful and surjective on objects.

Given a monad M on a category \mathcal {C}, there is a canonical adjunction between the category of algebras \mathcal {C}^M and \mathcal {C}. The forgetful functor U_M takes an algebra and forgets the algebra structure. The free functor F_M takes an object X and produces an algebra on MX given by the monad multiplication map \mu : M^2 X \to MX, called the free algebra.

We just have to verify that the two conversions are mutual inverses. In one way, we need to verify \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M f \mathbin {\circ } \eta = f. This is true because by the naturality of \eta we get M f \mathbin {\circ } \eta = \eta \mathbin {\circ } f. Then by the definition of algebra \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } \eta = \textrm {id}, proving the equality. On the other hand, we need to show \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M(\varphi \mathbin {\circ } \eta ) = \varphi . This follows from the algebra identity \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } M \alpha _Y = \alpha _Y \mathbin {\circ } \mu and the monad identity \mu \mathbin {\circ } M \eta = \textrm {id}.

A monad on a category \mathcal {C} is a functor M : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {C} equipped with natural transformations \eta : \textrm {Id} \to M and \mu : M \mathbin {\circ } M \to M satisfying identity and associativity laws. In an unbiased way, we have a family of natural transformations M^n \to M with associativity.
In short, it is a monoid in the category of endofunctors equipped with composition as the monoidal product.
